title: Barham Walks

images.title: David Anstiss / Flint and slate house in Barham
images.caption: Flint and slate house in Barham

images.title: David Anstiss / The River Nailbourne towards Barham
images.caption: The River Nailbourne towards Barham

images.title: David Anstiss / The Causeway, Derringstone
images.caption: The Causeway, Derringstone. This narrow lane leads from Valley Road towards a crossroads in the village. Beside is the River Nailbourne running through the village.

images.title: David Anstiss / Elham Valley Way leads towards Kingston
images.caption: Elham Valley Way leads towards Kingston. The long distance path heads from Covet Lane, towards Church Lane and St. Giles Church. In the background is Littlecourt House on Church Lane.

images.title: Nick Smith / Telephone box on Church Lane, Kingston.
images.caption: Telephone box on Church Lane, Kingston.

images.title: David Anstiss / Footbridge leading towards Bishopsbourne
images.caption: Footbridge leading towards Bishopsbourne. This bridge is on the Elham Valley Way (long distance path) heading towards Bishopbourne Church. The bridge leads over a section of the River Nailbourne.

images.title: North Downs Way beside Keepers Hill Wood by David Anstiss, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: North Downs Way beside Keepers Hill Wood

description: This pretty village is located within the Kent Downs AONB, just south of Canterbury. The village includes a 14th century church and the 17th century and Broome Park, a Grade I listed building with gardens. For walkers there are some fine trails taking you through the North Downs and the Elham Valley. This route uses sections of the Elham Valley Way and the North Downs Way to create a circular walk around the village. On the way there's nice views of the Nailbourne river, a tributary of the Little Stour. On the outward leg you'll visit Kingston, Charlton Park, Bishopsbourne, Bourne Park and Bridge. You then head through Bifrons Park before passing Higham Park, a Grade II* listed neoclassical style house and gardens. The route then crosses Barham Downs before returning to the village.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head into nearby Canterbury and you can visit the famous cathedral before enjoying a riverside stroll on the Stour Valley Walk. For more walking ideas in the area see the Kent Downs Walks page.

display_address: Derringstone Street, Barham, Canterbury, Kent, England, CT4 6QB, United Kingdom
